Release Notes: 

Sally forth of a Saturday evening into any one of BritainÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s 
murderous provincial town squares; the smell of testosterone 
mingles with sweating lambÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s flesh while punters duck into 
dive after dive as refugees pleading for sanctuary. What do 
you see? A zoo? Wild Beasts see a ballet. 

In Limbo, Panto this remarkable Leeds-via-Kendal four piece 
present a kind of Songs Of Innocence And Experience for the 
juvenile male psyche; cataloguing its obsessions, its foibles 
and its transferred desires with a satiristÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s eye for the 
absurd and an artistÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s eye for the absurdly beautiful. 

With lofty intent, then, the end justifies the frequently 
bewildering means: musically-speaking, Wild Beasts peddle an 
indecent but skilfully realised mix of village fete 
tomfoolery, Orange JuiceÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s subtle melodicism and, in frontman 
Hayden ThorpeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s divisive falsetto aneurisms, a diva croon to 
rival the oddball likes of Russell Mael and Billy McKenzie. 

With tracks like early calling-card &#039;Brave Bulging Buoyant 
Clairvoyants&#039;, Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Club Of Fathomless LoveÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ (Ã¢â‚¬Å“full with 
fierce, fathomless love / I spit and have spats to be roughÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½) 
Wild Beasts drink deep of the youthful elixir and dole out 
drubbings to the faces of their forefathers, only to find 
themselves undone in ways that have plagued mankind since time 
immemorial. Or not, as the case may be: Ã¢â‚¬ËœCheerio ChapsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is a 
grief-stricken music hall number examining what being shot out 
of a circus cannon will do for your wounded sense of male 
pride (Ã¢â‚¬Å“I gloat with gritted grin / to cheat my chin into 
keeping the womanly wibbling inÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½). 

To qualify a little: Limbo, Panto isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t a perfect debut, but 
in terms of range and depth of ambition thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s no new band in 
the UK can hold a candle to Wild Beasts right now, save 
perhaps These New Puritans, and theirs feels a much more 
consciously-willed autonomy, if no less valid. 

Which isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t to say our subjectsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ sound was merely stumbled 
upon; you can bet your bottom dollar there isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t a stroke on 
this record that wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t agonised over at length, and the band 
has clearly striven to create a lasting impression in 
everything from the track listing up Ã¢â‚¬â€œ ten songs in length, 
two previous singles left off (including the very fine 
Ã¢â‚¬ËœAssemblyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢), signature hit tucked away at track nine with 
muted arrangement, nary a furtive eye cast in the direction of 
the indie disco. Even the titleÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s jarring vowel sounds trip 
awkwardly off the tongue. 

And if Limbo, PantoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s opening brace are an exhilarating 
clatter then itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe DevilÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s CrayonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ that justifies the 
approach and provides the band with the masterstroke they were 
no doubt aiming at. ThorpeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s obsessively alliterative ear as a 
lyricist can occasionally get the better of him but here he 
allows himself room to breathe, bassist Tom FlemmingÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s suave 
tenor giving emotional heft to the formerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s impassioned cries 
that Ã¢â‚¬Å“we are all so much moulded doughÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ while revelatory 
chords fire off around him. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a pretty stunning moment. 

Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Old DogÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is a lovely, lilting duet that nonetheless 
sneaks lines as shocking and birth-traumatic as Ã¢â‚¬Å“a human is 
hauled from the wombÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s wired jawÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ under the radar, while 
highlight Ã¢â‚¬ËœHis Grinning SkullÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ provides another moment where a 
sense of transgression is allowed to pierce the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s 
rosy-cheeked vigour, an extraordinary tale of cuckoldry and 
gravedigging set to a stately shimmer of synth and guitar. 

A thrillingly uneven listen, all told, but what&#039;s important is 
that, like toddlers taking their first teetering steps, Wild 
Beasts are reeling in the instinctive knowledge theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve set in 
motion an idea thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been in their genes from birth, coursing 
fearless through learning limbs that seek out trauma as their 
cue to pick up the pen, the guitar or the microphone. As such, 
Limbo, Panto is shocking, funny, and above all irrevocable. 
Expect this lot to be around for the long haul.
